review.title: A Corpus of Sentence-level Revisions in Academic Writing: A Step towards Understanding Statement Strength in Communication
review.abstract: The strength with which a statement is made can have a significant impact on the audience. For example, international relations can be strained by how the media in one country describes an event in another; and papers can be rejected because they overstate or understate their findings. It is thus important to understand the effects of statement strength. A first step is to be able to distinguish between strong and weak statements. However, even this problem is understudied, partly due to a lack of data. Since strength is inherently relative, revisions of texts that make claims are a natural source of data on strength differences. In this paper, we introduce a corpus of sentence-level revisions from academic writing. We also describe insights gained from our annotation efforts for this task.

sections.heading: 5 Looking ahead
sections.text: Our observations on the results of the comments raise questions about what is a generalizable method of defining starch differences, how we use the labels we collect, and how we collect labels in the future. We believe that this corpus of sentence revisions, along with the labels and comments of participants, can provide insights into better ways to address this issue and help us better understand the strength of statements. An interesting direction that makes this possible is a potentially new type of learning problem. Comments point to characteristics that people think stand out. Is it possible to automatically learn new characteristics from the comments? The ultimate goal of our study is to understand the impact of meaningfulness on the public, which can lead to different applications in public communication.
